channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russia Presses on Eastern Front and Targets Final Fighters in Mariupol
item.description: Russian forces sought to destroy the last pocket of resistance at Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol, which would let President Vladimir V. Putin claim a major victory before Moscow’s military celebration on Monday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olga Podust, 28, surveyed the damage to her apartment in Kramatorsk, in eastern Ukraine, on Thursday. An overnight Russian airstrike severely damaged the residential complex where Ms. Podust lived.

item.title: India Finds Russian Oil an Irresistible Deal, No Matter the Diplomatic Pressure
item.description: A parade of emissaries have urged a harder line on Russia. But India’s political neutrality over the war in Ukraine has expanded into economic opportunism.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Stanley Reed
item.media:description: A Lukoil refinery in Volgograd, Russia.

item.title: Elon Musk Left a South Africa That Was Rife With Misinformation and White Privilege
item.description: The apartheid era created all-white enclaves littered with anti-Black government propaganda and sheltered from the atrocities of apartheid.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel

item.title: In Senegal’s Former Capital, a Colonial Statue in Hiding Is No Longer Welcome
item.description: The city of Saint-Louis was shaped by Louis Faidherbe, a French governor who also led brutal military campaigns in West Africa. What to do with his legacy has divided Senegal.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Carmen Abd Ali
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times

item.title: U.K. Local Elections Guide: What to Look For
item.description: National politics may not be front and center in voters’ minds, but how they cast their ballots could signal their opinions of the main parties.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
item.media:description: A voting site in Dobcross, northern England, during local elections on Thursday.

item.title: Anti-Putin Russians Are Leaving, With a Push From the Kremlin
item.description: Many Russians who are designated “foreign agents” by the government view it as another form of repression that makes living in the country, or returning to it, untenable.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russians who fled Russia following the government oppression and a fear of war gather at an apartment of a local volunteer to tell their life stories and share tips on how to settle in Istanbul. Many of them were activists or protested against war.

item.title: Nicaragua’s Secretive Ruling Family Reaches Out Quietly to the U.S.
item.description: Sanctions intended to thwart the president’s dictatorial actions have hit his family and inner circle hard. More pain is expected as sanctions hit Russia, an ally.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua with his wife and vice president, Rosario Murillo.

item.title: Iraqis Choke Under a Blanket of Dust as Sandstorms Sweep the Country
item.description: Orange skies signaled yet another dusty day for millions of Iraqis. It was the seventh such storm in recent months, and experts say more are on the way.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A sandstorm blanketing Baghdad on Wednesday.

item.title: What Is Russia’s May 9 Victory Day, and What Might Putin Say?
item.description: In the two decades that Vladimir V. Putin has led Russia, the country’s Victory Day marches, honoring Soviet sacrifices of World War II, have transformed into huge military spectacles and nostalgic celebrations.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Russian armored vehicles in the Victory Day military parade in 2021.

item.title: Why Boris Johnson Will Be Tested in UK by Local Elections
item.description: The British prime minister is under fire for lockdown-breaking parties. But many voters are skeptical that the opposition can solve issues such as soaring prices.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oliver Henry, center, at Chaps Barbers, a local business in Brandlesholme, in the political constituency of Bury North, England. Mr. Henry said he was not ready to abandon Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

item.title: In Mexico, One Cartel Is Cleared, but Others Storm In
item.description: In the state of Michoacán, small drug cartels compete with larger ones for territory, leaving the residents caught in the middle of a brutal turf war.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: Workers trying to contain a bush fire, lit by rival cartels to block access to a road used as an escape route into the mountains, in Uruapan, Mexico.

item.title: China’s Covid Lockdowns Leave Millions Out of Work
item.description: Migrant workers and recent college graduates have been hit hardest by shuttered factories, closed construction sites and an anemic job market.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Migrant workers waiting for jobs in Beijing in March. China’s Covid lockdowns have hit migrant workers especially hard.

item.title: China’s Covid Policies Have European Companies Wary of Investing
item.description: Lockdowns and supply chain issues have soured European businesses in China on the idea of further investment in the country, a survey finds.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Shanghai last week, under a full lockdown.

item.title: Turkey’s Plan to Draw Refugees Back to Syria: Homes for 1 Million
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan says Turkey will build homes, schools, hospitals and more in northern Syria, but experts question whether refugees will return willingly.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Elif Ince
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrian refugee children play near a large image of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey at a camp in southeast Turkey in 2019. Turkey houses more Syrian refugees than any other country.

item.title: Ricardo Alarcon, Diplomat and Castro Confidant, Dies at 84
item.description: As Havana’s go-between with the U.S., he negotiated Elián González’s return to Cuba. He was also the country’s U.N. representative on two occasions.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: At a United Nations meeting in 1972, Ricardo Alarcón of Cuba gave a speech in which he charged that Puerto Rico had been under U.S. colonial rule for 73 years. Mr. Alarcón was Cuba’s representative to the United Nations from 1966 to 1978 and again from 1990 to 1991.

item.title: Why the Battle for Mariupol Is Important for Putin
item.description: A victory in the predominantly Russian-speaking city could give a veneer of credibility to the Russian leader’s false claims of ridding Ukraine of “Nazis.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Russian state media are now highlighting Russia’s capture of almost all of Mariupol as a long-anticipated victory in Mr. Putin’s pledge to “denazify” Ukraine.

item.title: Europe’s Quest to Replace Russian Gas Faces Plenty of Hurdles
item.description: Climate concerns, investor reticence and political disputes complicate a shift to supplies from the United States, North Africa and the Mediterranean.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Jessica Lutz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The flaring of natural gas near Coyanosa, Texas. Europe is turning to the United States to make up part of the shortfall in its gas imports.

item.title: They Thought the Skulls Were Murder Victims’. They Were Off by Centuries.
item.description: Originally thought to be the remnants of gang killings, dozens of skulls found in a cave in southern Mexico are now believed to be from sacrificial killings more than 1,000 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: Human skulls found in a cave in the town of Carrizal, in the municipality of Frontera Comalapa, are thought to be from people who were sacrificed between A.D. 900 and 1200.

item.title: This Trump Play in London Is a Comedy. Unless You’re American.
item.description: Mike Bartlett’s “The 47th” presents political turmoil in the United States for laughs. But some find it more like a horror story.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Death Toll During Pandemic Far Exceeds Totals Reported by Countries, W.H.O. Says
item.description: Nearly 15 million more people died during the first two years of the pandemic than would have been expected during normal times, the organization found. The previous count of virus deaths, from countries’ reporting, was six million.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Transporting a Covid victim in New Delhi in April 2021. Nearly a third of excess deaths globally, some 4.7 million, took place in India.

item.title: ‘Not Good for Learning’
item.description: New research is showing the high costs of long school closures in some communities.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Heaven Shaw, 11, doing remote school work.

item.title: Searching for What Connects Us, Carlo Rovelli Explores Beyond Physics
item.description: The physicist ranges widely — from black holes to Buddhism to climate change — in his new book, “There Are Places in the World Where Rules Are Less Important Than Kindness.”
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Cannariato
item.media:credit: Chloe Ellingson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new book by Carlo Rovelli, a physicist, explores questions of how we live now.

item.title: Why Climate Change Makes It Harder to Fight Fire With Fire
item.description: Worsening wildfires in recent years have led officials to embrace planned fires to thin forests before disaster strikes. But the warming world is making it tougher to do safely.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Modoc National Forest firefighter used a drip torch to ignite a prescribed burn in Alturas, Calif., last year.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A planned embargo on Russian oil.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Bulgaria’s sole oil refinery, the Russian-owned Lukoil Neftochim Burgas, on the country’s Black Sea coast.

item.title: Stanislav Shushkevich, First Leader of Post-Soviet Belarus, Dies at 87
item.description: He helped formalize the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991, led his country until 1994, then became a vocal critic of his successor, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger

item.title: Putin Could Use Russia’s Victory Day to Expand Ukraine War, Some Fear
item.description: The Russian holiday celebrating the Soviet triumph over Nazi Germany is viewed by Ukraine and NATO as a stage for the Russian president to proclaim a turn in the war.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Michael Levenson

item.title: Moderna Reaps $5.9 Billion From Its Vaccine Sales
item.description: Stéphane Bancel, the company’s chief executive officer, said Moderna has $21 billion worth of advance purchase agreements for the vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Coral Murphy Marcos
item.media:description: Boxes of the Moderna vaccine were prepared for shipment in Olive Branch, Miss.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Ban on Russian Oil?
item.description: The E.U. proposed a total embargo.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: The PCK oil refinery, which is majority owned by Russian energy company Rosneft and processes oil coming from Russia via the Druzhba pipeline in Germany.

item.title: NOAA Image Catches Wildfire Smoke and Dust on Collision Course
item.description: A time-lapse image of smoke from wildfires in New Mexico and dust from a storm in Colorado illustrates the scope of Western catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor

item.title: European Union Takes a Leap With a Russian Oil Embargo
item.description: The ban, once seen as unlikely, is a significant tightening of the squeeze on Russia’s economy, and a financial blow to Europe, too.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Bulgaria’s sole oil refinery, the Russian-owned Lukoil Neftochim Burgas, near the city of Burgas, on the country’s Black Sea coast.

item.title: Putin-Linked Superyacht May Elude Sanctions, by Setting Sail
item.description: The Italian police are in a race to finish investigating a $700 million vessel thought to be the Russian president’s — before it’s out of their reach.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani and Michael Forsythe
item.media:description: After months in a dry dock, the Scheherazade was put into the water on Tuesday. Port workers say it has been fueled up and loaded with supplies.

item.title: John Doerr Gives Stanford $1.1 Billion for Climate School
item.description: The billionaire venture capitalist said the study of climate change and sustainability would be the “new computer science.”
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Carolyn Fong for The New York Times

item.title: In Pakistan, Violence by Baluch Separatists Destabilizes Region
item.description: A government plagued by volatility is trying to quell a separatist movement in Baluchistan while also fighting other insurgencies and striving for economic development.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: A suicide bomber destroyed a passenger van at the entrance of a Chinese cultural center in Karachi, Pakistan, on April 26, killing four others.

item.title: Saving Ukrainian Art, and Helping Artists, One NFT at a Time
item.description: Lika Spivakovska, the owner of two art galleries in Kyiv, Ukraine, has partnered with an NFT gallery in Puerto Rico to auction off pictures of art damaged and created during the war. The money will go to Ukrainian artists and other humanitarian aid.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: Lika Spivakovska closed her two art galleries in Kyiv, Ukraine, a week into the war. She converted damaged artworks into digitized NFTs that were exhibited and sold at Lighthouse, an NFT art gallery in Puerto Rico.

item.title: Roe Inspired Activists Worldwide, Who May Be Rethinking Strategy
item.description: Feminist movements in some countries similarly sought abortion protections in their courts, but for others, the goal was legislative change.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abortion rights protesters celebrating in front of Colombia’s Constitutional Court during the ruling in favor of decriminalizing abortion up to 24 weeks gestation, in Bogota, Colombia, in February.

item.title: A Trump Win in Ohio
item.description: We look at last night’s election results.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: J.D. Vance after winning the Ohio Republican Senate primary.

item.title: A Crumbling Russian ‘Spyville’ Returns to Polish Hands
item.description: A Warsaw housing complex built in the 1970s and rented by Russia was reputed to be a nest of spies. The city’s government has seized the site and pledged to hand it over to the Ukrainian community.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: The abandoned former Soviet diplomatic housing complex in Warsaw. The city has seized the building and plans to turn it into accommodation for Ukrainian refugees.

item.title: Japan Says It Needs Nuclear Power. Can Host Towns Ever Trust It Again?
item.description: The Ukraine war has shown the fragility of Japan’s energy supplies. But the decision to restart plants after the Fukushima disaster is fraught with emotions and political calculation.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Haruka Sakaguchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: An idled nuclear power plant, including its large steel towers, looms over the coastal communities of Kashiwazaki and Kariwa along the Sea of Japan.

item.title: Covid and Omicron Variants: Lessons From Gamma, Iota and Mu
item.description: Studying the coronavirus variants that have faded away could help us prepare for what comes next, scientists say.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: For every Delta or Omicron there is a Gamma, Iota or Mu, variants that caused local surges but never swept to global dominance. There are lessons to be learned from these lesser lineages, researchers say.

item.title: E.U. to Propose Total Ban on Russian Oil Imports
item.description: The proposal will be presented in detail to E.U. ambassadors Wednesday and is expected to be adopted by the end of the week.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen delivering her speech during a debate on the social and economic consequences for the EU of the Russian war in Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: North Korea Launches Ballistic Missile Ahead of Yoon’s Inauguration
item.description: Kim Jong-un has sought to improve the North’s nuclear capabilities and gain diplomatic leverage with Washington and the incoming administration of Yoon Suk-yeol.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A TV at Seoul’s main railroad station on Wednesday broadcasts file footage of a North Korean missile launch, in a news report of the latest such weapons test.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Shockwaves from a Supreme Court leak.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abortion rights advocates surrounded anti-abortion activists in front of the Supreme Court on Tuesday after a draft of an opinion overruling Roe v. Wade leaked.

item.title: Handful of Virus Cases Emerge After White House Correspondents’ Dinner
item.description: Cases are not uncommon in Washington these days, and there is no certainty that those who tested positive were infected at the dinner.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil

item.title: Sensing a Stalled Russia, West Adds Support and Arms for Ukraine
item.description: ‘You have exploded the myth of Putin’s invincibility,’ Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain told Ukrainian lawmakers, one of several Western sources of cheerleading on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Jason Horowitz
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.media:description: President Biden greeting employees at a Lockheed Martin facility that makes weapon systems including Javelin anti-tank missiles, on Tuesday in Troy, Ala.

item.title: Britain’s Parliament Is Rocked by Sexist Episodes. Again.
item.description: Encouraging more women to run for office, critics say, is just one way to counter pervasive misogyny and sexual harassment in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: The Palace of Westminster, Britain’s seat of Parliament, in London.

item.title: Russian Missiles Hit Power Stations in Lviv and Along Crucial Railways
item.description: Altogether, six electrical substations were struck along the railways in central and western Ukraine, according to a top rail official. The rail system is the country’s lifeline for humanitarian and military supplies.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising from the site of a Russian missile attack in the western city of Lviv, Ukraine, on Tuesday evening.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: The End of Roe?
item.description: Abortion is in jeopardy in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abortion rights advocates surrounded anti-abortion activists in front of the Supreme Court yesterday.

item.title: Beijing Tightens Measures as Some Residents Grow Weary
item.description: Authorities are trying to avoid a full-scale lockdown in the Chinese capital like the one imposed in Shanghai.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien and Amy Qin
item.media:description: Disinfectant being sprayed outside a restaurant after the government banned dine-in service in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: 6 Podcasts That Go Deeper on the Headlines
item.description: These series, on subjects like the war in Ukraine, the storming of the U.S. Capitol and the 1921 Tulsa race massacre, can help combat news fatigue.
item.dc:creator: Emma Dibdin

item.title: Russia’s War Has Been Brutal, but Putin Has Shown Some Restraint. Why?
item.description: Western officials are debating the Kremlin’s calculations in not trying harder to halt weapons shipments in Ukraine. Analysts wonder whether a bigger mobilization by Moscow is on the horizon.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rescue worker on an upper floor of an apartment building hit by a Russian missile strike in central Kyiv, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Evacuees From Azovstal Steel Plant Tell of Horrors and Survival
item.description: Nearly 130 people reached relative safety after sheltering for weeks in dark bunkers under the Azovstal plant, under constant bombardment, with dwindling food.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Almost 130 evacuees from Mariupol arrived in Zaporizhzhia, in southeastern Ukraine, on Tuesday after spending weeks hiding in bunkers underneath the Azovstal steel plant.

item.title: Smithsonian Adopts Policy on Ethical Returns in a Nod to Changing Norms
item.description: The institution’s leaders hope other cultural centers will follow its lead. It has already announced plans to return most of its collection of Benin Bronzes to Nigeria under the new policy.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: The Smithsonian Institution has adopted a policy that makes clear its commitment to return items from its collection that it determines were looted or had been otherwise acquired unethically.

item.title: Boris Johnson Calls Russia War ‘Ukraine’s Finest Hour’
item.description: In the first address by a foreign leader to Ukraine’s Parliament, Britain’s prime minister burnished his credentials as a supporter of the resistance to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain addressing Ukrainian lawmakers via videolink, in Kyiv, on Tuesday.

item.title: Roe, on the Edge
item.description: Roe v. Wade seems to be on the cusp of falling.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters at the Supreme Court.

item.title: What Sanctions Have Been Imposed on Russia?
item.description: Our reporters answer readers’ questions about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Many of you asked about economic penalties and how Putin could respond.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: The Russian oil producer Gazprom Neft's oil refinery on the outskirts of Moscow in April.

item.title: Israel Plans Zip Line for Ancient Jerusalem
item.description: A Jewish settler group is promoting projects that opponents say will change the delicate historic, religious and political balance in highly symbolic areas around Jerusalem’s Old City.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Palestinian neighborhood of Silwan in East Jerusalem below the Old City walls. Known as the holy basin, the area around the ramparts is dotted with archaeological ruins and shrines of the major monotheistic religions.

item.title: Cuban Migrants Arrive to U.S. in Record Numbers, on Foot, Not by Boat
item.description: Political repression and escalating economic difficulties on the island, along with a new visa-free travel policy in Nicaragua, are some of the factors driving the change.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Eileen Sullivan
item.media:description: Yaquemile, a migrant from Cuba, wading through the Rio Grande from Mexico into Texas in April.
